case_title: GIRIJAN COOPERATIVE CORPORATION LTD. vs COMMISSIONER OF INCOME-TAX
complaint_summary: The appellant claimed exemption from income tax under Section 11 of the Income-tax Act, 1961, asserting its status as a public charitable institution under Section 2(15). The Revenue disputed this, arguing the corporation's activities were commercial in nature.
investigation_summary: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reviewed the corporation's bye-laws and concluded its activities were commercial, not charitable, and denied tax exemption. The corporation appealed this decision.
judgment_summary: The court held that the predominant object of the corporation was charitable, aimed at uplifting Scheduled Tribes, and not earning profits. It ruled the corporation qualifies as a public charitable institution under Section 2(15) and its income is exempt under Section 11.
Decision_or_verdict: Order accordingly. The corporation qualifies as a public charitable institution under Section 2(15) and its income is exempt under Section 11.
legal_arguments: The appellant argued its activities were aimed at improving the economic conditions of Scheduled Tribes, qualifying as 'relief of the poor' and 'advancement of general public utility' under Section 2(15).
The Revenue contended the corporation's activities were commercial, with profits distributed as dividends, disqualifying it from tax exemption.
citations: 1980 121 ITR 1 (Surat Art Silk Cloth Manufacturers' Association case)
1988 170 ITR 476 (A.P. Bankers and Pawnbrokers Association case)
1986 159 ITR 1 (A.P. State Road Transport Corporation case)
key_issues: Whether the corporation qualifies as a public charitable institution under Section 2(15) of the Income-tax Act, 1961.
Whether its income is exempt under Section 11 of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

key_points.assessee_objective: Relief of Scheduled Tribes and advancement of their economic and social welfare.
key_points.tribunal_findings: Activities are commercial in nature and not held under trust for charitable purposes.
key_points.court_ruling: The corporation's predominant object is charitable, focusing on the upliftment of Scheduled Tribes, and its income qualifies for exemption under Section 11.

objects: Purchase and marketing of Scheduled Tribes' produce.
Supply of necessities to Scheduled Tribes.
Promotion of economic and social welfare of Scheduled Tribes.
bye-laws_summary.profit_distribution: Reserve fund, education fund, dividends (capped at 6.25%), and bonuses.

legal_terms.Charitable Purpose: Includes relief of the poor, education, medical relief, and advancement of any other object of general public utility not involving the carrying on of any activity for profit.

words_and_phrases.General Public Utility: Activities aimed at benefiting a sizable number of the public without the primary objective of earning profit.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the classification of Girijan Cooperative Corporation Ltd. as a public charitable institution under Section 2(15) of the Income-tax Act, 1961. The court ruled in favor of the appellant, emphasizing its predominant charitable purpose aimed at uplifting Scheduled Tribes, despite incidental profits.
